Award.AwardTitle: Cyber Security: Cyber First Responder Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
St. Philip's College (SPC), a public, two-year Historically Black College and Hispanic Serving Institution in San Antonio, Texas, launched a new Cyber Security: Cyber First Responder Program with funding support from the National Science Foundation. The project's goal is to educate and prepare cyber first responders to increase the number of professionals in the information assurance and cyber security workforce who are highly trained to prevent, detect, respond to, and recover from cyber security incidents impacting one or more organizations.

The project's activities include professional development for SPC college faculty and area K-12 educators, creation of a certificate program for emergency operations personnel, development of curriculum leading to an Associate of Applied Science degree in Cyber First Response, formation of collaborative agreements with 4-year institutions to provide transitions to 4-year programs to complete a Bachelor or higher degree, development of a secondary school component for middle and high school students as well as the creation of a cyber-learning laboratory at SPC.

This project is producing a skilled group of cyber first responders capable of implementing basic cyber security prevention measures, collaboratively identifying intrusive activity when it occurs using research-based best practices to respond to incidents from an organizational viewpoint, and implementing innovative approaches to resolve incidents that impact more than a single organization. As a result, this project is leading to the development of a model cyber first responder program that may be replicated at other institutions. Additionally, it creates and optimizes a regional network of productive cyber first responder partnerships between academia, businesses, and industries in South Texas and the nation.

Performance_Institution.Name: St. Philip's College-Alamo Community College District

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary intent of the St. Philip’s College Cyber Security: Cyber First Responders Program is to develop programs to create the Cyber First Responders that Texas and the nation will need for the fast-growing cyber security workforce.  The target population for this project includes Information Technology (IT) Technicians, information security personnel, emergency response personnel, CFR associate degree candidates, college students interested in pursuing a four year degree in CFR, and middle and high school students interested in the CFR career path.  St. Philip’s College conducted recruitment efforts for the project to include persons from diverse and traditionally underrepresented groups including females, racial minorities, low socioeconomic status, persons with disabilities, and veterans. 

 The project goals focused on addressing the identified needs and creating a curriculum and courses that comprised the larger Cyber First Responders Program.  The four accomplished project goals are outlined below:

GOAL 1 – Created a Cyber First Responder Certificate Program for instructional technology and emergency operations personnel needing an understanding of cyber incident response. 

Objectives met:

  1. Ninety percent (90%) of SPC IT faculty will attended one (1) information assurance and cyber security professional development conferences/trainings per year during the three-year project period related to the CFR certificate program.
  2. Developed 100% of the curriculum for the courses under the CFR certificate program by May 2014.
  3. Begin offering the first CFR courses under the certificate program as of Fall 2014.
  4. During the 2014-2015 academic year, the full sequence of courses for the CFR certificate program were offered.

GOAL 2  – Developed the curriculum leading to an Associate of Applied Science degree in Cyber First Responder.

Objectives met:

  1. Ninety percent (90%) of SPC IT faculty will attended one (1) information assurance and cyber security professional development conferences/trainings per year during the three-year project period related to the CFR Associate degree program.
  2. During the 2013-2014 academic year, modification were conducted to current Network Security Administrator courses for the two-year associate degree curriculum for the Cyber First Responder Program.
  3. During the Fall 2014 semester, St. Philip's College began offering courses for the CFR two-year associate degree curriculum program.
  4. Recruited 10% of Marketable Skills Certificate Award and Certificate completers into Associate Degree Program over the three-year project period.

 GOAL 3 – Formed collaborative agreements with four-year institutions to provide transitions to four-year programs for individuals to continue their Cyber First Response education beyond the two-year level.

Objectives met:

  1. Created professional development seminars to collaborate, build curriculum, and facilitate the information assurance and cyber security field of study career pathway from secondary schools to two-year colleges to four-year universities (2 + 2 + 2).
  2. By Year 2, St. Philip's College established a 2 + 2 program with local partner four-year institutions of higher education.
  3. During the 2013-2014 academic year, St. Philip's College created programs in cyber security response.
  4. Established an exchange of curriculum with four-year colleges/universities by creating a common curriculum committee.

GOAL 4 – Developed a secondary school component for high school students with an interest in cyber security to explain the purpose and value of this program as a potential college major and career choice.

Objectives met:

  1. During 2013-2014 academic year, St. Philip's developed a curriculum and training program in cyber first responders for high school teachers and students.
  2. During 2014-2016, St. Philip's College offered periodic professional development in information assurance, cyber security, and CFR for middle and high school teachers.
  3. During summers 2014-2016, St. Philip's College offered a summer camp for middle and high school students with a focus on information assurance and cyber security.

Accomplishments

Designation: National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense 2014-2020

St. Philip’s College and the National Science Foundation Cyber Security: Cyber First Responders Program hosted  (120) college-wide membership drives and Secondary Schools Cyber Events.

  • 120 Cyber Security engaging workshops
  • Outreached to 5,120 students around San Antonio School Districts
  • Engaged with 13 School Districts

STEM Symposium:

The STEM Symposium event was to establish a robust, sustainable framework and integrate workforce and educational pipelines through partnering of resources.

  • 70 Participants

Cyber First responders Conference

  • 265 participants from Community Organizations, Government, Industry, Public Education, Students and Universities

Agreements with high schools to facilitate awareness and training for faculty/administration/students

  • Agreements with Harlandale and Southwest High School
  • Junior Cyber Security Summer Camps
  • St. Philip’s College sponsored a Cyber Security Summer Camps for grades 7-12 students.
  • Junior Cyber Security Summer Camps had a total of 100 students
  • (100% met NSF Cyber First Responders grant objectives).
  • Participating Middle Schools and High Schools: 21 Middle Schools: and 20 High Schools: 20

Security + training course prepared IT/Security professionals for the CompTIA Security+ certification exam.

Summer Security + Training/CIAS-UTSA

  • 16 participants: July 8-12, 2013
  • 13 participant July 15-19, 2013

Summer Digital Forensics Training

  • Summer Digital Forensics Training had a total of (29) participants.
  • (100% met National Science Foundation Cyber First Responders grant objectives)

Last Modified: 10/13/2016
Modified by: Haydar Sahin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The primary intent of the St. Philip?s College Cyber Security: Cyber First Responders Program is to develop programs to create the Cyber First Responders that Texas and the nation will need for the fast-growing cyber security workforce. The target population for this project includes Information Technology (IT) Technicians, information security personnel, emergency response personnel, CFR associate degree candidates, college students interested in pursuing a four year degree in CFR, and middle and high school students interested in the CFR career path. St. Philip?s College conducted recruitment efforts for the project to include persons from diverse and traditionally underrepresented groups including females, racial minorities, low socioeconomic status, persons with disabilities, and veterans. The project goals focused on addressing the identified needs and creating a curriculum and courses that comprised the larger Cyber First Responders Program. The four accomplished project goals are outlined below: GOAL 1 – Created a Cyber First Responder Certificate Program for instructional technology and emergency operations personnel needing an understanding of cyber incident response. Objectives met: Ninety percent (90%) of SPC IT faculty will attended one (1) information assurance and cyber security professional development conferences/trainings per year during the three-year project period related to the CFR certificate program. Developed 100% of the curriculum for the courses under the CFR certificate program by May 2014. Begin offering the first CFR courses under the certificate program as of Fall 2014. During the 2014-2015 academic year, the full sequence of courses for the CFR certificate program were offered. GOAL 2 – Developed the curriculum leading to an Associate of Applied Science degree in Cyber First Responder. Objectives met: Ninety percent (90%) of SPC IT faculty will attended one (1) information assurance and cyber security professional development conferences/trainings per year during the three-year project period related to the CFR Associate degree program. During the 2013-2014 academic year, modification were conducted to current Network Security Administrator courses for the two-year associate degree curriculum for the Cyber First Responder Program. During the Fall 2014 semester, St. Philip's College began offering courses for the CFR two-year associate degree curriculum program. Recruited 10% of Marketable Skills Certificate Award and Certificate completers into Associate Degree Program over the three-year project period. GOAL 3 – Formed collaborative agreements with four-year institutions to provide transitions to four-year programs for individuals to continue their Cyber First Response education beyond the two-year level. Objectives met: Created professional development seminars to collaborate, build curriculum, and facilitate the information assurance and cyber security field of study career pathway from secondary schools to two-year colleges to four-year universities (2 + 2 + 2). By Year 2, St. Philip's College established a 2 + 2 program with local partner four-year institutions of higher education. During the 2013-2014 academic year, St. Philip's College created programs in cyber security response. Established an exchange of curriculum with four-year colleges/universities by creating a common curriculum committee. GOAL 4 – Developed a secondary school component for high school students with an interest in cyber security to explain the purpose and value of this program as a potential college major and career choice. Objectives met: During 2013-2014 academic year, St. Philip's developed a curriculum and training program in cyber first responders for high school teachers and students. During 2014-2016, St. Philip's College offered periodic professional development in information assurance, cyber security, and CFR for middle and high school teachers. During summers 2014-2016, St. Philip's College offered a summer camp for middle and high school students with a focus on information assurance and cyber security.
